item.title: Use Lightroom Classic only as a DAM tool for FREE
item.description: TLDR: After your adobe lightroom subscription ends, you still have access to all your local photos, and use all the modules except for the Develop and Map modules. This means you can still import new photos and manage all your photos with Lightroom’s tagging, keyword, filter and even quick develop functions, which makes it possible to use LrC as a standalone DAM (digital asset management) software and leave complex editing tasks to other dedicated softwares like GIMP and Capture NX-D.

item.title: A Chinese character tool - translate to Pinyin and extract radical
item.description: Sometimes I have the need to translate large amount of Chinese characters to Pinyins and extract the corresponding radicals. Recently I found this js library ‘cnchar’ which exactly meets my need. Using the library I created this page for convience.

item.title: Update local lensfun database for Darktable
item.description: I just give up using Lightroom. Because I had to reinstall my system after Christmas, so I choose to try and install Manjaro along with the OEM Windows10. Taking this opportunity, I spent some time transfered all my photo collections from Lightroom 6 to Darktable. The darktable used Lensfun library to perform lens correction. Lensfun have collected a lot of lens and camera data. By now (2020-02-28) there’re 1057 lenses in the database, and all the popular cameras are covered.

item.title: Get p-values for effects/variables from (g)lmer models
item.description: For some reason (see GLMM FAQ and here for more detail), the lmer function in the lme4 package doesn’t provide p-values for the coefficients (i.e., whether the betas you got are different from 0 or not). If you use lme4::glmer, you’ll find that there are p-values listed in the summary of the model. However, I found two problems of them. item.title: Birding in Point Pelee National Park
item.description: Two week ago, we went to the Point Pelee National Park to watch the migrating birds (mainly warblers). It’s a wonderful experience. We saw a lot of birds that we have never seen before in local area.
